Award.AwardTitle: Analyzing the Role of Social Networks in Local Government Decision-Making about High-Volume Hydraulic Fracturing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates how social networks shape policy decision-making about high-volume hydraulic fracturing (HVHF), a technique for hydrocarbon extraction that is transforming the U.S. energy landscape. The research explores how the structure of local government networks affects the efficacy of policy entrepreneurs (sometimes known as "leaders" or "issue advocates") in convincing local officials in California and New York to adopt HVHF policies. The project also evaluates how the social networks of policy entrepreneurs affect the innovativeness of local HVHF policies. Finally, it analyzes the social mechanisms driving decision-makers? (non)participation in the diffusion of HVHF policies among sub-state jurisdictions. This research advances scholarship by drawing insights from network science that allow quantitative analysis of how human agents' policy entrepreneurs and local government officials' engage with social networks and influence policy diffusion. In addition to its scientific contributions, this research and associated outreach will help local government officials learn how to leverage their information networks most effectively when seeking information about HVHF or other issues of salience to local governance. Such learning is particularly important given the sharp capacity constraints these officials often face. Another important output of this project is an online decision-support tool that will help local officials learn about HVHF policy options. This free, searchable web interface will house hundreds of digitized, archived, and categorized pro- and anti-HVHF policy measures passed by sub-state jurisdictions in California and New York.

This project uses social network analysis to illuminate blind spots in policy scholarship. Policy diffusion is clearly a network-reliant process, yet policy scholars all but ignore how learning, imitative, or competitive inter-jurisdictional pressures experienced by local officials may shape diffusion patterns. They also rarely examine the content of policies subject to diffusion. Research on policy entrepreneurs, individuals who push a policy onto the public agenda and help secure its passage, acknowledges the importance of networks in facilitating entrepreneurial advocacy yet devotes little attention to the mechanisms that drive this influence. Scholars who do tackle these questions rarely use quantitative methods. The project addresses these gaps. It quantitatively tests hypotheses about how aspects of policy entrepreneurs? social networks affect their success in convincing decision makers to adopt policy innovations, how ties among municipal decision makers can reveal the social mechanisms underlying policy diffusion, and how policy entrepreneurship can shape the innovativeness of policies and their rate of uptake.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the ways in which social networks influence the policy choices that local governments make about a new fossil fuel extraction technique called high-volume hydraulic fracturing (fracking), the nature of those choices, and how policy advocacy influences them. For example, research resulting from this grant shows that anti- and pro-fracking advocacy by interested stakeholders can make local decision-makers more likely to pass anti- or pro-fracking policies, respectively. ?Local? is defined as city, village, or town level; this project specifically focused on local jurisdictions in the State of New York, with secondary analysis in two other states.

 

Research supported by this grant shows that success of local fracking policy advocates is affected by the connections they have with peers, decision-makers, and other stakeholders; these connections are conduits for information and resources relevant to advocacy. Advocates who have more contacts with supporters are more likely to see their preferred policy adopted. Anti-fracking advocates are more successful when they can loop otherwise unconnected interests into a broad, loose coalition, while pro-fracking advocates are more successful when they can forge high-value connections with key decision-makers. This work was published in the journal Policy Studies.

 

The grant also supported research which finds that local jurisdictions are more likely to adopt anti-fracking policies when their neighbors do so, suggesting that jurisdictions? learn from or mimic their peers when making fracking policy choices. A step-wise strategy can be successful for anti-fracking advocates targeting localities: Jurisdictions which adopt weaker anti-fracking policies (e.g., non-substantive resolutions) are more likely to pass more stringent policies (e.g., a fracking ban) later on. This work was published in the journal Public Administration Review.

 

Additionally, the grant supported analysis of the nature and efficacy of narratives deployed by anti- and pro-fracking advocates. The two sides use different persuasive strategies as they seek to influence the choices of local decision-makers. Pro-fracking advocates rely on economic arguments, while anti-fracking advocates deploy emotional appeals about potential environmental damage and health impacts. Anti-fracking advocates tend to demonize their opponents (those supporting fracking), while pro-fracking advocates tend to emphasize the goodness or heroic nature of their coalition and its interests (that is, the oil and gas industry). This research was published in Policy Studies Journal.

 

Other projects this research supported include analysis of the ways in which decision-makers obtain, process, and use information when making choices about local fracking policies (currently under review at Policy Sciences); analysis of the factors affecting whether jurisdictions adopt pro-fracking policies (published in Review of Policy Research); analysis of how policy networks estimated from local newspapers are similar to or different from those estimated from public meeting minutes (current under review at Policy Studies); analysis of the strategies used by advocates seeking to steer local decision-makers in California toward fracking restrictions; and analysis of how anti-fracking advocacy organizations in Colorado and California seek stakeholder support and engagement, with particular focus on how groups engage with marginalized groups (i.e., poor, non-white) often particularly adversely affected by fracking.

 

The grant provided a foundation for ongoing research. With its support, we have collected data for more than 100 jurisdictions in a four-county region of New York. These data will allow us to estimate the networks of fracking policy participants in these jurisdictions; we have constructed networks for about half them, and are working on more. We will use these networks to understand how channels of information and resource-sharing among policy participants influence the rate and extent of diffusion of policies across jurisdictions.

 

This research has been shared at national academic conferences such as the annual meetings of the American Political Science Association?s annual meeting and the Association for Public Policy, Analysis, and Management. We are currently preparing policy briefs that will summarize primary findings in a manner accessible to policymakers, stakeholders, and members of the public.

 

A number of graduate and undergraduate students have been supported and trained using resources provided by this grant, to their personal and professional benefit. Six undergraduates have been paid an hourly rate for their research assistance, while three graduate students have received tuition and stipend support. Additionally, approximately 67 undergraduates have worked as unpaid interns on grant-associated research, collecting, organizing, and analyzing data. The grant has therefore allowed students to gain research skills and professional experience, preparing them for future careers and increasing their prospects of securing a job post-graduation. It has given students first-hand experience with the operations of local government and policy advocacy, as well as a close understanding of dynamics associated with fossil fuel production. This knowledge can help students move into careers in research, local government, advocacy, or planning.
